posts.text: Same. I'm proposing that the opportunity for that "click" only exists for systems for which we 1. can characterize some notion of stability (homeostasis) and 2. the system is frustrated wrt that stable state. Returning the system to its stable orbit is identical to need satisficing.

reply_context.text: Organisms have needs which certain elements in the environment can satisfy. Hence, I'm positing some form of analogous primitive organism-environment "click"

posts.text: Through this lens, the focus is shifted to characterizing *dissatisfaction* as a restoring force towards homeostasis. The "feeling of satisfaction" in this light would then be better characterized as an absence of frustration, where frustration could take any of a variety of forms. 2/2

reply_context.text: I think a positive experience exists to which we often ascribe the emotion of "satisfaction", but strictly speaking I'd posit that this is inverted relative to how we should think of a "primitive feeling of satisfaction" i.e Drive Reduction Theory. 1/2
